class.name: Word.Bibliography
class.description: Represents the list of available sources attached to the document (in the current list) or the list of sources available in the application (in the master list).

properties.name: bibliographyStyle
properties.description: Specifies the name of the active style to use for the bibliography.

examples.description: Set the bibliography style to APA (American Psychological Association) format for the document's bibliography.

properties.name: context
properties.description: The request context associated with the object. This connects the add-in's process to the Office host application's process.

examples.description: Access the bibliography's request context to verify the add-in is properly connected to the Word host application before performing bibliography operations.

properties.name: sources
properties.description: Returns a SourceCollection object that represents all the sources contained in the bibliography.

examples.description: Get all sources from the document's bibliography and display the count and title of each source in the console.

methods.name: generateUniqueTag
methods.description: Generates a unique identification tag for a bibliography source and returns a string that represents the tag.

examples.description: Generate a unique tag for a new bibliography source before adding it to the document's bibliography

methods.name: load
methods.description: Queues up a command to load the specified properties of the object. You must call context.sync() before reading the properties.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides options for which properties of the object to load.

params.name: propertyNames
params.description: A comma-delimited string or an array of strings that specify the properties to load.

params.name: propertyNamesAndPaths
params.description: propertyNamesAndPaths.select is a comma-delimited string that specifies the properties to load, and propertyNamesAndPaths.expand is a comma-delimited string that specifies the navigation properties to load.

examples.description: Load and display the number of sources in the document's bibliography

methods.name: set
methods.description: Sets multiple properties of an object at the same time. You can pass either a plain object with the appropriate properties, or another API object of the same type.

params.name: properties
params.description: A JavaScript object with properties that are structured isomorphically to the properties of the object on which the method is called.

params.name: options
params.description: Provides an option to suppress errors if the properties object tries to set any read-only properties.

examples.description: Update bibliography settings to set the bibliography style to APA and enable automatic updates

methods.name: toJSON
methods.description: Overrides the JavaScript toJSON() method in order to provide more useful output when an API object is passed to JSON.stringify(). Whereas the original Word.Bibliography object is an API object, the toJSON method returns a plain JavaScript object (typed as Word.Interfaces.BibliographyData) that contains shallow copies of any loaded child properties from the original object.

examples.description: Serialize the document's bibliography data to JSON format and log it to the console for debugging or export purposes.

methods.name: track
methods.description: Track the object for automatic adjustment based on surrounding changes in the document. This call is a shorthand for context.trackedObjects.add(thisObject). If you're using this object across .sync calls and outside the sequential execution of a ".run" batch, and get an "InvalidObjectPath" error when setting a property or invoking a method on the object, you need to add the object to the tracked object collection when the object was first created. If this object is part of a collection, you should also track the parent collection.

examples.description: Track a bibliography object to maintain its reference across multiple sync calls while adding sources and updating properties

methods.name: untrack
methods.description: Release the memory associated with this object, if it has previously been tracked. This call is shorthand for context.trackedObjects.remove(thisObject). Having many tracked objects slows down the host application, so please remember to free any objects you add, once you're done using them. You'll need to call context.sync() before the memory release takes effect.

examples.description: Access the document's bibliography, perform operations with it, then untrack it to free memory after use.
